Heterogeneous cobalt-complex catalyst for wacker-type oxidation of styrene by balloon O2 Chengke Chang Writing – original draft Yuelei Hou Data curation Jun Li Writing – review & editing ⁎ School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shanghai Institute of Technology Shanghai 201418 China School of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Institute of Technology, Shanghai 201418, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Heterogeneous Cobalt-based Catalysts were prepared by coordination reaction of Co(OAc)2 with diverse ligands grafted to surface-modified mesoporous silica. The catalysts were characterized by using X-ray diffraction, Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Ultra-violet-visible spectroscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption, disclosing the structure of the species, the content and chemical state of cobalt in the catalyst. The performance of the catalyst was evaluated with Wacker-type oxidation of styrene and its derivatives by atmospheric-pressure balloon O2. The novel catalyst exhibited high activity at room temperature of 20 °C. Moreover, the conversion of styrene and the yield of the goal product reached 98.5 % and 80.1 % respectively under optimum conditions. The stability of the catalyst and the heterogeneity of the reaction were proved by catalyst recycling test and hot-filtration test. A mechanism of the oxidation reaction was proposed tentatively according to our experiment and some reports in the literature. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous cobalt-complex catalyst Wacker-type oxidation Styrene styrene derivatives Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Wacker-type oxidation process involves the selective oxidation of alkenes to aldehydes or ketones, catalyzed by PdCl2 as the primary catalyst and CuCl2 as a co-catalyst under aerobic conditions, which is one of the first and the most important applications of transition metal catalysis in industry [1]. However, the procedure involves the decomposition of palladium, isomerization of olefins and formation of chlorination byproducts, especially high concentrations of chlorine can cause significant corrosion to equipment. These shortcomings limit the application of Tsuji-Wacker oxidation process [2,3]. Various efforts have been made to overcome these deficiencies and promote the development and application of the Wacker reaction. CuCl2 was replaced by less corrosive non-halide chemicals such as Cu(OAc)2 [4]. Some inorganic and organic oxidants, like H2O2, benzoquinone (BQ), and tert‑butyl hydrogen peroxide (TBHP), can serve as excellent oxidants for the Wacker reaction or alternatives to copper (II) salts [5–7]. In addition, the catalyst active components and solvent are also undergoing changes. Han et al. [8] reported that FeCl2 (10–20 mol%) was used as a catalyst to oxidize olefins into ketones with high selectivity towards the target product. Kang et al. [9] developed a Pd(PhCN)2/t-BuONO catalytic system for the Wacker-type oxidation of internal olefin, in which both aromatic and chain olefin can be converted into target product with good yield and high regional selectivity. The Schiff-base complexes of the transition metal, as inorganic mimics of enzymes, have been extensively studied due to their potentialities as catalysts in a wide range of oxidation reactions [10]. Homogeneous metal Schiff base complexes have garnered widespread attention in the field of catalysis because of their high activities in the oxidation reactions [11]. However, homogeneous catalysts have some drawbacks, e.g. difficulties in catalyst separation and recycling [12]. To address these limitations, the heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts has emerged as an important research area as it allows for the design of eco-friendly catalysts [13–15]. Covalent bonding is considered as a highly effective method for fixing homogeneous metal complexes [16]. Long et al. functionalized magnetic particles using three different ligands and immobilize palladium acetate with a facile method, resulting in three heterogeneous catalysts [17]. When utilizing H2O2 as an oxidant and Fe3O4@SiO2-β-diketimine-Pd(OAc)2 as a catalyst, the selectivity of goal product reached 94 %, significantly surpassing that of homogeneous catalysts. However, the precious metal palladium is used as the active component in this process and the conversion rate of the reaction was low (71 %). In recent years, the environmental-friendly Wacker-type oxidation process received more and more attention [18]. However, the catalysts used were mainly concentrated in the precious metal palladium [19]. From an environmental and economic perspective, the development of a heterogeneous system with non-noble metal catalyst has far-reaching significance for the selective oxidation of olefins. Here, we report four Schiff base cobalt-based heterogeneous catalysts and corresponding Wacker oxidation systems. The newly synthesized Schiff base ligands were grafted onto the mesoporous material SBA-15 with the help of 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), and a series of cobalt-based multiphase catalysts were prepared by coordination reaction. Styrene and its derivatives were selectively oxidized to ketone by atmospheric-pressure balloon O2 under mild reaction conditions. The catalyst displayed high activity even at room temperature. The results show that the heterogeneous cobalt-based catalyst has good catalytic activity and stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods Cobalt acetate (Co(OAc)2, 98.0 %), ethylenediamine (99.0 %), styrene (99.0 %), methanol (99.5 %) and acetonitrile (99.5 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %), tert‑butyl hydrogen peroxide (TBHP, 70.0 % in water), ethanol (99.7 %), N, N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, 99.0 %) were provided by Shanghai Titan Technology Co., Ltd. 5-(chloromethyl) −2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (97.0 %) were obtained from Shanghai Meryer Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals are analytical grade and used without further purification. Characterization of small angle diffraction was performed using a Bruker D8 Advance instrument, with Cu palladium Ka rays (λ = 0.154 nm) as the excitation source and scanning at 0.5 min-1 in the range of 0.5–10°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB 250 Xi spectrometer equipped with an Al Ka X-ray excitation source with a control voltage of 14 KV and a power of 250 W. FT-IR spectra were recorded using a NICOLET iZ10 with 64 scans between 400 and 4000 cm-1. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrum was measured on Hitachi U-3900 UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrometer. The N2 adsorption/desorption data were obtained with the Tristar II Plus Version 3.03 (Micromeritics). 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of SBA-15 Mesoporous material SBA-15 was synthesized by using triblock copolymer (P123) as template and tetraethyl orthosilicate as silicon source under weakly acidic environment. Referring to the synthesis procedure by Zhao et al., with minimal modifications [20]. 4.0 g P123 and 120.0 g 2 mol/L hydrochloric acid were added to a 500 mL three-necked flask containing 30 g deionized water, stirring in a water bath at 35 °C until the P123 was completely dissolved, then dropping 8.4 g tetraethyl orthosilicate into the solution, stirring at 35 °C for 24 h. The white emulsion was transferred to a teflon-lined autoclave, sealed and heated in an oven to 120 °C, kept for 72 h. After the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The solid was separated from the solution by vacuum filtration, washed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, dried in oven at 80 °C. The dried solid was then transferred to the Muffle furnace, calcinated at 550 °C for 6 h to obtain SBA-15. 2.2.2 Amination of SBA-15 (SBA-15-A) 1.0 g SBA-15 was dispersed into 100 mL of anhydrous xylene in a 250 mL round-bottom flask, followed by adding 1.3 g of APTES and 20 mL of chloroform, stirring under reflux for 24 h, and then cooling down to room temperature. The obtained white solid was washed multiple times with chloroform and dried at 80 °C for 10 h to get a white powder, denoted as SBA-15-A. 2.2.3 Synthesis of N, N’-bis (5-chloromethyl salicylidene) ethylenediamine schiff base (CM-Salen ligand) 5-chloromethyl-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde (3.41 g, 20.0 mmol) was dissolved in CH2Cl2 (10 mL) under nitrogen atmosphere. ethylenediamine (0.60 g, 10.0 mmol) was then added dropwise to the mixture and stirred at room temperature for 24 h. After filtration, washing and drying, a bright yellow crystal was obtained, which was named CM-Salen ligand. The 1H NMR result was shown in the Figure S3. 1H NMR (401 MHz, DMSO‑d6): δ = 10.26 (s, 2H), 8.44 (s, 2H), 7.83 (s, 2H), 7.57 (s, 2H), 7.45 (s, 1H), 7.17 (s, 1H), 4.47(s, 4H), 3.95 (s, 4H). 2.2.4 Synthesis of SBA-15-A-Salen The CM-Salen ligand was covalently anchored to SBA-15-A through nucleophilic reaction. Here are the steps: 0.50 g SBA-15-A was first dispersed in toluene to form a suspension, then 0.36 g CM-Salen ligand was added and heated under nitrogen for 24 h by reflux. The obtained SBA-15-A-Salen solid was filtered, cleaned by methylbenzene, extracted by CH2Cl2, and then dried in the air. The final product was labeled as SBA-15-A-S. 2.2.5 Synthesis of catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co Under the protection of nitrogen gas, 1.0 g SBA-15-A-S prepared above was dispersed in 20 mL methyl alcohol, and then Co(OAc)2 - methyl alcohol (0.1 g, 10 mL) solution was added, stirred at room temperature for 24 h, and then filtered. The solid was washed with large amount of methyl alcohol and water in turn. The solid catalyst was obtained after vacuum drying. The final catalyst was recorded as SBA-15-A-S-Co (ICP-AES showed a cobalt content of 1.268 wt%). The preparation scheme of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 1 . In order to compare the effects of ligand structures, 5-chloromethyl-2-hydroxybenzaldehyde was condensed with o-phenylenediamine (R1), cyclohexanediamine (R2), and 1, 3-propylenediamine (R3) respectively to produce different Schiff base ligands (Fig. 2 ). After the similar steps 2.2.4 and 2.2.5, the corresponding catalysts obtained were denoted as SBA-15-A-S1 Co, SBA-15-A-S2 Co and SBA-15-A-S3 Co. 2.3 Oxidation reaction The catalytic reaction was carried out in a glass reactor equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a reflux condenser. A certain amount of catalyst and 3 mL of solvent were put into the flask, followed by adding 1 mmol of reaction substrate and 2 equivalent additives, stirring fully, and raising the temperature to the set value. Then atmospheric-pressure balloon oxygen was connected, starting the reaction after replacing the air in the reactor. After the reaction, the mixture underwent filtration, extraction and evaporation. The final organic phase was analyzed by gas chromatography GC-2060 quipped with a capillary column (30 m in length, 0.32 mm i.d., and 0.25 µm in film thickness) and a flame ionization detector (FID) (Shanghai Ruimin Instrument Co., Ltd), using n-butanol as the internal standard. The filtered catalyst was washed with a large amount of ethanol and vacuum dried overnight for the next reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization 3.1.1 FT–IR characterization FT-IR spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 3 . The peaks at 463, 805 and 1082 cm-1 correspond to the bending vibration, symmetric stretching vibration and asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si respectively [21]. The weak absorption band at 958 cm-1 is caused by Si-OH stretching vibration on the surface of SBA-15. The absorption peaks at 2934 cm-1 and 2990 cm-1 indicate the presence of methylene in APTES. After grafting of Schiff base to SBA-15-A, a larger new absorption peak can be observed at 1640–1650 cm-1, which is ascribed to the C = N tensile vibration [22]. For SBA-15-A-S-Co, the absorption band shifts to a lower frequency, appearing around 1639 cm-1, indicating that nitrogen in the ligand has a coordination effect with the metal. This may be because the lone-pair electrons of N transfer to the metal, causing the electron cloud of the C = N bond to shift towards the metal ion, resulting in a decrease in the electron cloud density of C = N. The absorption peak in the range of 534–541 cm-1 in the complex is attributed to the coordination between the metal and oxygen atoms [23]. 3.1.2 UV–vis characterization UV–vis spectra of the solids are shown in Fig. 4 . The absorption peaks at 200–400 nm in the figure indirectly indicate that the Schiff base ligand was successfully grafted onto SBA-15. In SBA-15-A-S, the two absorption peaks at 254 nm and 400 nm are attributed to the π - π * and n - π * charge transfer transitions of the double bond in the ligand [24]. In SBA-15-A-S-Co, when the metal coordinates with the ligand, the absorption peak shifts towards longer wavelengths. This may be due to the charge transfer transition from the ligand to the metal. 3.1.3 XRD characterization The XRD patterns of SBA-15 and catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen from the small-angle XRD pattern of SBA-15 that the diffraction peak at 2θ = 0.90° corresponds to the crystal face of SBA-15 mesoporous material (100). The two relatively weak peaks at 2θ = 1.54° and 1.77° correspond to the second order diffraction peak of the (110) crystal plane and the second order diffraction peak of the (200) crystal plane, respectively [25], demonstrating that the material is of mesoporous structure. For the sample SBA-15-A-S-Co, the three characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to (100), (110), and (200) still exist. But the position of the characteristic diffraction peak of the (100) crystal plane shifts to 2θ = 0.93°. According to the Bragg formula 2dsinθ = nλ, it can be inferred that the interplanar spacing decreases as 2θ increases. Therefore, the reason for the decrease in the interplanar spacing of d100 is that the grafted complex enhances the interaction between the mesoporous material layers [26]. The relative intensity of the prominent diffraction peak (100) decreases, which may be due to the mutual coordination between the silicate skeleton and organic components located in the channels of the SBA-15 [27]. In summary, it can be proved that the synthesized support SBA-15 conforms to the characteristics of mesoporous structure, and indirectly indicates the successful preparation of SBA-15-A-S-Co material. 3.1.4 XPS characterization The chemical state of SBA-15-A-S-Co was studied using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . As expected, the peaks corresponding to C, N, O, Co, and Si elements can be clearly observed in the wide scan XPS spectrum (Fig. 6a and c), in which the N element may originate from N-containing ligands, reflecting the successful graft of the ligands. For the fresh catalyst, the typical binding energy of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 at 781.0 eV and 796.1 eV, with the satellite peaks at 785.7 eV and 802.5 eV, are characteristic of Co2+ species (Fig. 6b) [28–30]. The XPS spectra of Co 2p for the used catalyst were shown in Fig. 6d. The peaks at approximately 780.0 eV and 795.1 eV were attributed to the Co3+ of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, while the peaks located at 781.1 eV and 796.0 eV corresponded to Co2+ of Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 respectively. Three weak satellite peaks of Co 2p are observed at 782.8 eV, 785.3 eV, and 802.2 eV, possibly being due to the presence of different local environments of the Co atoms [31]. These observations indicated that cobalt mainly existed in a divalent state in the fresh catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co, while in the used catalyst, cobalt mostly existed in a trivalent state. 3.1.5 N2 adsorption / desorption characterization Fig. 7 shows the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of synthesized SBA-15 and SBA-15-A-S-Co. The isotherms of the SBA-15 before and after modification were both of type IV adsorption. There were H1 hysteresis loops for the two samples, indicating that the grafting of the complexes did not change the mesoporous structure of the SBA-15 material, being consistent with the above XRD characterization results. The adsorption and desorption curves of SBA-15-A-S-Co are similar in trend to SBA-15, but move towards smaller pressures, resulting in a decrease in adsorption capacity and hysteresis curve, indicating a change in the pore size. Meanwhile, this effect is also manifested in a significant decrease in BET specific surface area and BJH pore volume of the supported catalyst. The pore size distribution of the material is reflected in Fig. 8 , where the catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co shows a decrease in pore size, indicating that some organic groups and active metal components may have entered the mesoporous channels. The data in Table 1 shows that the specific surface area of the catalyst decreased from 554.76 m2/g of the SBA-15 to 234.57 m2/g, and the pore volume also decreased from 1.02 cm3/g to 0.49 cm3/g, indicating the successful loading of the metal complex. 3.2 Performance of the catalysts 3.2.1 Influence of different ligands on catalytic performance The effects of ligand structures on catalytic performance are shown in Table 2 . When SBA-15-A-S-Co was used as a catalyst, the yield of acetophenone was 80 %, and only a small amount of the by-product 1-phenylethanol was detected (entry 1). The yields of the main product acetophenone with catalyst SBA-15-A-S1 Co, SBA-15-A-S2 Co, or SBA-15-A-S3 Co (entries 6–8) were much lower than that with SBA-15-A-S-Co (entry 1), which may be ascribed to electronic effects of the complex catalysts, large steric hindrance, or special structural differences. The low catalytic activity of SBA-15-A-S1 Co may be attributed to the strong rigidity of the ligand due to the presence of benzene ring group [32], and the conjugation effect of benzene ring made the lone pair electrons of nitrogen atoms partially delocalize to the benzene ring, thereby causing an impact. The reason for the low activity of SBA-15-A-S2 Co may be attributed to the larger steric hindrance of the connecting group R2 [33]. The catalytic effect of SBA-15-A-S3-Co is better than that of SBA-15-A-S1 Co and SBA-15-A-S2 Co, indicating that the flexibility of the ligand is beneficial for the reaction. However, due to the elongation of the connecting groups in SBA-15-A-S3 Co, either enhanced distortions in the N2O2 plane or more drastic changes in its geometry [34] resulted in a lower yield compared to that with catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co. The simple ligand structure of SBA-15-A-S-Co may be relatively flexible with low steric. Furthermore, smaller steric hindrance is conducive for substrates to approach the active center of the catalyst, leading the better catalyticperformance (entry 1). In air atmosphere (entry 2), the yield of acetophenone is far less than that under O2 atmosphere (entry 1), while the goal product was hardly detected under N2 atmosphere (entry 3). The above results indicated that as an oxidant, the concentration of oxygen played an important role in the reaction system. In addition, as a free radical scavenger, the addition of TEMPO greatly inhibited the reaction (entry 4). It can be speculated that a free radical mechanism is likely to be involved in the Wacker oxidation of styrene. When styrene oxide (as shown in parentheses below the Table 2) was used as substrate instead of styrene, almost no acetophenone was found after 4 h reaction (entry 5), indicating that styrene oxide was not involved in the oxidation of styrene. In contrast, the yield of the goal product acetophenone was a little bit higher [17] in the system with hydrogen peroxide as the oxidant and precious metal palladium complex as the catalyst. In order to understand the impact of the catalyst's physical properties on the reaction, mesoporous MCM-41material was synthesized and utilized to immobilize Schiff base complexes and prepare the catalyst MCM-41-A-S-Co via the procedures described in the supplementary material (1). The physical parameters of the synthesized materials MCM-41 and MCM-41-A-S-Co were demonstrated in Figure S1, S2 and Table S1. The Wacker-type oxidation of styrene was conducted on MCM-41-A-S-Co under the same conditions as those on SBA-15-A-S-Co. The results showed that the conversion of the substrate and the yield of the main product on catalyst MCM-41-A-S-Co were inferior to those on catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co (Table S2), which may be due to the fact that SBA-15-A-S-Co possesses a larger pore volume and pore size compared to MCM-41-A-S-Co (Table S1), facilitating the diffusion of reactant and product molecules [35]. 3.2.2 The influence of additives on catalytic performance The effects of the additives on the catalytic performance were studied as shown in Table 3 . No reaction was detected without additive, indicating that additives are indispensable in the catalytic oxidation process. The additives can also regulate the reaction pathway and the selectivity of products [36]. When two equal quantities of phenylsilane (PhSiH3) were added, the conversion of the substrate styrene reached 98.5 %, and the yield of the target product acetophenone reached 80.1 %. However, when equal amount of polymethylhydrosiloxane (PMHS) or triethylsilane were added, the conversions of the substrate styrene were only 18.2 % and 22.6 %, respectively, and the selectivity of the product was only about 20 %. These may be attributed to the differences in the structure and chemical properties of the additives. Knölker et al. [37] proved that silane participated in the reaction as hydride donor in the study of iron-catalyzed Wacker-type oxidation of olefin, reported that PhSiH3 was the hydrosilane with the best performance, and confirmed that the catalytic active intermediate reacted with hydrosilane to form the key metal hydride. Abuhafez et al. [38] studied the influence of triethylsilane through experiments and calculation methods. They suggest that the catalytic cycle begins with the oxidation of the lower ionic complex to the higher ionic hydride in the presence of silane, and show that the formation of the higher ionic hydride is the determining step of the overall reaction rate. Based on the above reports and our experimental results, it is speculated that PhSiH3 can play a role as a hydride donor to form the catalytically active cobalt (III) hydride species Co-H. 3.2.3 The influence of solvents on catalytic performance For heterogeneous catalysis, solvents often play a crucial role. The effects of solvents are shown in Table 4 . When acetonitrile, ethanol, methanol, dimethylformamide (DMF), and isopropanol were used as solvents respectively, the results showed that the yield of acetophenone was 3.7–80.1 %. Furthermore, when ethanol and methanol were used as solvents, the conversion can reach over 98 %, and the yields of the goal product can be up to 80.1 % and 71.4 %, respectively. More recently, An et al. [39] reported a Co-N/C catalytic system for the similar Wacker-type oxidation in which isopropanol (iPrOH) served as a hydrogen source and solvent, the reaction occurred in the presence of 20 mol % K2CO3 at 150 °C under 4 bar O2 atmosphere. In contrast, when isopropanol was used as solvent here, the yields of the goal acetophenone were only 24.5 % and 3.7 % with or without phenylsilane respectively. It is speculated that this may be related to O2 pressure, temperature as well as other additives. In addition, presumably solvent ethanol promoted the binding of active cobalt to substrates and then facilitated the target reaction [37]. 3.2.4 The influence of catalyst dosage The increase of catalyst dosage from 0.005 g to 0.02 g exhibited a positive correlation with the reaction results, as shown in Table 5 . Afterwards, the conversion basically unchanged with the increase of the catalyst, but the selectivity decreased to some extent. Presumably, excess catalyst may cause deep oxidation, leading to a decline in the goal product. When the amount of catalyst is 0.01 g, the TOF(162 h-1) is the highest, however, the yield under this condition is relatively low. When the amount of catalyst increased to 0.02 g, the yield of acetophenone reached its highest, while its TOF value remained at a relatively high level. Therefore, 0.02 g catalyst may be the optimal dosage. 3.2.5 The influence of temperature Appropriate reaction temperature can improve the catalytic effect. The effects of temperature on catalytic performance were invetigated, as shown in Table 6 . It's interesting that the conversion and selectivity reached 89.2 % and 69.2 % respectively after 4 h reaction at room temperature of 20 °C, reflecting the outstanding catalytic activity of the catalyst. Further increase in temperature significantly improved both the conversion and selectivity. However, the selectivity slightly decreased when the temperature exceeded 50 °C. This may be due to excessive oxidation of the product, and resulting in an increase of by-products. 3.3 Catalyst cycling experiment The reusability of SBA-15-A-S-Co was examined through catalyst-cycling experiment. The specific experimental steps were as follows: after the reaction was complete, the solid catalyst was separated from the mixture by centrifugation and filtration, then washed and dried for the next experiment. These steps were repeated 5 times, and the resulting data were summarized in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that there was no significant decrease in catalyst performance. The conversion of the substrate remained above 95 %, and the selectivity could be maintained above 70 %. This may be attributed to the enhanced stability of the catalyst achieved by the unique anchoring of salen cobalt complexes on the SBA-15-A. XPS analysis was conducted on the reused catalyst (Fig. 6c and d). It can be seen that the spectral lines of the elements C, N, O, Co, and Si on the catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co after five cycles all appear on the full spectrum of the catalyst (Fig. 6c). The high-resolution spectrum (Fig. 6d) of Co2p for the reused catalyst displayed new peaks at approximately 780.0 eV and 795.1 eV, indicating partial oxidation of Co. FT–IR measurement was also conducted on the catalyst after five cycles. The Infrared spectrum (Figure S4) of the reused catalyst was the same as that (Fig. 3) of the fresh catalyst. Additionally, the cobalt content (1.132 wt %) in the catalyst slightly decreased after 5 cycles compared with the fresh catalyst (1.268 wt %) according to the results of ICP measurement, indicating that a little cobalt in the catalyst leached into the solution. These results indicate that the catalyst has good reusability. 3.4 Hot filtration experiment Hot filtration experiment was conducted to determine whether the supported Co-complex were responsible for the reaction. The catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by hot filtration after 1 h reaction. Then the mother liquid was left to react for another 4 h without changing the original conditions. The data obtained were plotted in Fig. 10 . It can be observed that the yield of the goal acetophenone did not increase with time, while the reaction almost stopped after the removal of the solid catalyst, proving the heterogeneity of the catalyst and the catalytic reaction. 3.5 Substrate expansion Our cobalt-based heterogeneous catalytic system was applicable for a wide scope of styrene derivatives as summarized in Table 7 . The yields of the corresponding ketones lay in 69–78 %. The results may be subjected to the structure of the substrates, such as substituents on the phenyl ring. Furthermore, electron-withdrawing groups, like chlorine, bromine and nitro group (entries 4–8) may have a negative influence on the yields. On the contrary, the yields of the target product were higher when the benzene ring contained electron-donating groups (entries 1–3). The reason for these may be related to the electron cloud density of alkenes in styrene derivatives. In addition, the tert‑butyl and phenyl groups with large steric hindrance in the benzene ring have adverse effects on the yield of the target ketone. 3.6 Possible mechanism When the experiment was carried out in the air (no balloon O2), the yield of target product was about 25 % (Table 2, entry 2). However, under N2 condition, the reaction did not occur (Table 2, entry 3). It can be speculated that O2 may be an essential oxidant in the system. In addition, the conversion of the substrate was significantly reduced when radical trapping agent TEMPO was added (Table 2, entry 4). Presumably, the catalytic reaction underwent a radical reaction mechanism. In addition, the styrene oxide as a substrate has no reactive activity, so epoxidation/isomerization pathway can be ruled out (Table 2, entry 5) [40,41]. According to the experiment (Table 3), it can be seen that phenylsilane is conducive to promoting the transformation of the substrate and improving the selectivity of the product, indicating that phenylsilane may participate in the reaction. hydrosilane sources usually acted as a hydrogen-transferreagent in the Wacker oxidation reaction with cobalt(II)-based catalyst [38]. which was also confirmed in the above experiment. The catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co presented excellent catalytic performance as shown above, While poor catalytic effect was found with cobalt-free material SBA-15-A-S (Table S2, entry 4). In addition, the material SBA-15-A had little catalytic effect for the talked reaction (Table S2, entry 3). In short, The Salen-type ligand synthesized herein could significantly promote the catalytic performance of the catalyst SBA-15-A-S-Co with cobalt as the active center for the Wacker oxidation of aromatic olefin. Based on our experiments and relevant literature [42–46], a possible reaction mechanism is proposed (Fig. 11 ). First, cobalt (II) transforms into cobalt (III) hydride Co-H in the presence of oxygen and phenylsilane. The hydride then interacts with the substrate to form cobalt-alkyl intermediate a. Next, a reacts with oxygen to form peroxide species b. After further rearrangement of species b, the final product methyl ketone and cobalt hydroxyl are generated. The latter reacted with phenylsilane reagent to generate active cobalt hydride, and completing the catalytic cycle. The consecutive dehydrogenative coupling of phenylsilane with alcohol was substantiated by the time-dependent spectra [42]. Phenylsilane here in our reaction system may convert to PhSi(OEt)3 after the reaction. The detailed mechanism of this reaction is currently being studied. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully synthesized heterogeneous Schiff-base cobalt catalysts and developed an environment-friendly and efficient reaction system for the Wacker oxidation of styrene and its derivatives. In this system, only atmospheric-pressure balloon O2 was used as oxidant and ethanol was used as solvent. The reaction conditions are mild. The novel catalyst presented high activity even at room temperature of 20 °C. The catalyst has good stability and can be recycled many times without significant loss in its performance. Under optimal conditions, the conversion of the substrate styrene can reach 98.5 %, and the selectivity of the target product can reach 81.3 %. We are still conducting relevant studies to optimize the reaction system further. CRediT authorship contribution statement Chengke Chang: Writing – original draft. Yuelei Hou: Data curation. coredata.dc:description: Heterogeneous Cobalt-based Catalysts were prepared by coordination reaction of Co(OAc)2 with diverse ligands grafted to surface-modified mesoporous silica. The catalysts were characterized by using X-ray diffraction, Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Ultra-violet-visible spectroscopy and N2 adsorption/desorption, disclosing the structure of the species, the content and chemical state of cobalt in the catalyst. The performance of the catalyst was evaluated with Wacker-type oxidation of styrene and its derivatives by atmospheric-pressure balloon O2. The novel catalyst exhibited high activity at room temperature of 20 °C. Moreover, the conversion of styrene and the yield of the goal product reached 98.5 % and 80.1 % respectively under optimum conditions. The stability of the catalyst and the heterogeneity of the reaction were proved by catalyst recycling test and hot-filtration test. A mechanism of the oxidation reaction was proposed tentatively according to our experiment and some reports in the literature.
